unnormalised: Hey everyone, your friendly neighbourhood foodie here! Today, I want to chat about something we all do pretty regularly: buying sabzi and groceries. But let's be real, understanding quantities and measurements at the local market can be a total adventure, right?
normalised: Hey everyone, your friendly neighborhood foodie here! Today, I want to chat about something we all do pretty regularly: buying sabzi and groceries. But let's be real, understanding quantities and measurements at the local market can be a total adventure, right?

unnormalised: Remember that time I tried to make matar paneer? The recipe called for 250 gm of paneer, but I totally eyeballed it, and ended up with enough paneer to feed the entire neighbourhood! Let's just say my matar paneer became "paneer with a side of matar". And don't even get me started on trying to figure out how many "pao" of bhindi I need. Is it ½ kg? Is it ¼ kg? My brain starts doing calculations like I'm back in school.
normalised: Remember that time I tried to make matar paneer? The recipe called for two hundred and fifty gram of paneer, but I totally eyeballed it, and ended up with enough paneer to feed the entire neighborhood! Let's just say my matar paneer became "paneer with a side of matar". And don't even get me started on trying to figure out how many "pao" of bhindi I need. Is it half kilogram? Is it quarter kilogram? My brain starts doing calculations like I'm back in school.

unnormalised: See, we usually hear measurements in various ways. The vendor might say, "Ek pao tamatar, Didi," or "Adha kilo pyaaz." Then there are the recipes, which often use cups and spoons - "1 tbsp haldi," "½ tsp mirchi powder." Converting all this in your head while juggling your shopping bags is truly a skill.

unnormalised: And it’s not just weight! Volume plays a big part too, especially when buying liquids. "1 liter doodh," the milkman shouts. Then you're trying to remember if that's the same as 1000 ml or if you're missing something. The juice wala asks if you want 200ml or 300 ml of fresh juice, adding to the confusion!

unnormalised: I’ve learned a few tricks over the years. For example, most small plastic bags hold about 250g of something. So, if you need roughly 1kg of potatoes, ask for "char bags, bhaiya." Also, many vendors still use the "tola" system for spices. Find out what 1 tola equals in grams (it's usually around 11.66g, but ask around!), and you'll be a spice-buying pro.

So, if you need roughly one kilogram of potatoes, ask for "char bags, bhaiya." Also, many vendors still use the "tola" system for spices. Find out what one tola equals in grams (it's usually around eleven point sixty six gram, but ask around!), and you'll be a spice-buying pro.

unnormalised: One of my favourite hacks is using a reusable shopping bag as a rough gauge. If it feels comfortably full of onions, you're probably around the 2 kg mark. It's not precise, but it’s way better than guessing! Plus, you're being eco-friendly, which is always a bonus.

unnormalised: So, the next time you head out to buy your weekly groceries, remember to embrace the chaos of Indian measurements. A little bit of gyan about "pao" versus "kg" and "ml" versus "liter" can go a long way in making your shopping experience a bit smoother. And hey, even if you mess up, at least you'll have a funny story to tell, right? Happy shopping, and may your matar paneer always have the perfect paneer-to-matar ratio!
